rajawali.materials

Class Material

  • java.lang.Object
    • rajawali.renderer.AFrameTask
      • rajawali.materials.Material

  • public class Material
extends AFrameTask
    The Material class is where you define the visual characteristics of your 3D model. Here you can specify lighting parameters, specular highlights, ambient colors and much more. This is the place where you add textures as well. For an overview of the different types of materials and parameters visit the Rajawali Wiki. https://github.com/MasDennis/Rajawali/wiki/Materials This is a basic example using lighting, a texture, Lambertian diffuse model and Phong specular highlights: 
    
 Material material = new Material();
 material.addTexture(new Texture("earth", R.drawable.earth_diffuse));
 material.enableLighting(true);
 material.setDiffuseMethod(new DiffuseMethod.Lambert());
 material.setSpecularMethod(new SpecularMethod.Phong());
 
 myObject.setMaterial(material);
    Author:
    dennis.ippel

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  Material.PluginInsertLocation
      This tells the Material class where to insert a shader fragment into either the vertex of fragment shader.

    • Field Detail

      • mVertexShader

        private VertexShader mVertexShader
        The generic vertex shader. This can be extended by using vertex shader fragments. A vertex shader is typically used to modify vertex positions, vertex colors and normals.

      • mFragmentShader

        private FragmentShader mFragmentShader
        The generic fragment shader. This can be extended by using fragment shader fragments. A fragment shader is typically used to modify rasterized pixel colors.

      • mLightsVertexShaderFragment

        private LightsVertexShaderFragment mLightsVertexShaderFragment
        The shader fragments that are plugged into both the vertex and fragment shader. This is where lighting calculations are performed.

      • mDiffuseMethod

        private IDiffuseMethod mDiffuseMethod
        The diffuse method specifies the reflection of light from a surface such that an incident ray is reflected at many angles rather than at just one angle as in the case of specular reflection. This can be set using the setDiffuseMethod() method: 
        
 material.setDiffuseMethod(new DiffuseMethod.Lambert());

      • mSpecularMethod

        private ISpecularMethod mSpecularMethod
        The specular method specifies the mirror-like reflection of light (or of other kinds of wave) from a surface, in which light from a single incoming direction (a ray) is reflected into a single outgoing direction. This can be set using the setSpecularMethod() method: 
        
 material.setSpecularMethod(new SpecularMethod.Phong());

      • mUseVertexColors

        private boolean mUseVertexColors
        Indicates that this material should use a color value for every vertex. These colors are contained in a separate color buffer.

      • mLightingEnabled

        private boolean mLightingEnabled
        Indicates whether lighting should be used or not. This must be set to true when using a DiffuseMethod or a SpecularMethod. Lights are added to a scene RajawaliScene and are automatically added to the material.

      • mTimeEnabled

        private boolean mTimeEnabled
        Indicates that the time shader parameter should be used. This is used when creating shaders that should change during the course of time. This is used to accomplish effects like animated vertices, vertex colors, plasma effects, etc. The time needs to be manually updated using the setTime(float) method.

      • mIsDirty

        private boolean mIsDirty
        Indicates that one of the material properties was changed and that the shader program should be re-compiled.

      • mProgramHandle

        private int mProgramHandle
        Holds a reference to the shader program

      • mVShaderHandle

        private int mVShaderHandle
        Holds a reference to the vertex shader

      • mFShaderHandle

        private int mFShaderHandle
        Holds a reference to the fragment shader

      • mModelMatrix

        private float[] mModelMatrix
        The model matrix holds the object's local coordinates

      • mModelViewMatrix

        private float[] mModelViewMatrix
        The model view matrix is used to transform vertices to eye coordinates

      • mColor

        private float[] mColor
        The material's diffuse color. This can be overwritten by Object3D.setColor(int). This color will be applied to the whole object. For vertex colors use useVertexColors(boolean) and setVertexColors(int).

      • mAmbientColor

        private float[] mAmbientColor
        This material's ambient color. Ambient color is the color of an object where it is in shadow.

      • mAmbientIntensity

        private float[] mAmbientIntensity
        This material's ambient intensity for the r, g, b channels.

      • mColorInfluence

        private float mColorInfluence
        The color influence indicates how big the influence of the color is. This should be used in conjunction with ATexture.setInfluence(float). A value of .5 indicates an influence of 50%. This examples shows how to use 50% color and 50% texture: 
        
 material.setColorInfluence(.5f);
 myTexture.setInfluence(.5f);

      • mTime

        private float mTime
        Sets the time value that is used in the shaders to create animated effects. 
        
 public class MyRenderer extends RajawaliRenderer
 {
                private double mStartTime;
                private Material mMyMaterial;
 
                protected void initScene() {
                        mStartTime = SystemClock.elapsedRealtime();
                        ...
                }
 
                public void onDrawFrame(GL10 glUnused) {
                        super.onDrawFrame(glUnused);
                        mMyMaterial.setTime((SystemClock.elapsedRealtime() - mLastRender) / 1000d);
                        ...
                }

      • mLights

        protected java.util.List<ALight> mLights
        The lights that affect the material. Lights shouldn't be managed by any other class than RajawaliScene. To add lights to a scene call {@link RajawaliScene#addLight(ALight).

      • mPlugins

        protected java.util.List<IMaterialPlugin> mPlugins
        A list of material plugins that are used by this material. A material plugin is basically a class that contains a vertex shader fragment and a fragment shader fragment. Material plugins can be used for custom shader effects.

      • mOwnerIdentity

        protected java.lang.String mOwnerIdentity
        This texture's unique owner identity String. This is usually the fully qualified name of the RajawaliRenderer instance.

      • mMaxTextures

        private int mMaxTextures
        The maximum number of available textures for this device. This value is returned from Capabilities.getMaxTextureImageUnits().

      • mTextureList

        protected java.util.ArrayList<ATexture> mTextureList
        The list of textures that are assigned by this materials.

      • mNormalFloats

        protected final float[] mNormalFloats
        Contains the normal matrix. The normal matrix is used in the shaders to transform the normal into eye space.

      • mNormalMatrix

        protected Matrix4 mNormalMatrix
        Scratch normal amtrix. The normal matrix is used in the shaders to transform the normal into eye space.

      • mCustomVertexShader

        protected VertexShader mCustomVertexShader

      • mCustomFragmentShader

        protected FragmentShader mCustomFragmentShader

    • Constructor Detail

      • Material

        public Material()
        The Material class is where you define the visual characteristics of your 3D model. Here you can specify lighting parameters, specular highlights, ambient colors and much more. This is the place where you add textures as well. For an overview of the different types of materials and parameters visit the Rajawali Wiki. https://github.com/MasDennis/Rajawali/wiki/Materials This is a basic example using lighting, a texture, Lambertian diffuse model and Phong specular highlights: 
        
 Material material = new Material();
 material.addTexture(new Texture("earth", R.drawable.earth_diffuse));
 material.enableLighting(true);
 material.setDiffuseMethod(new DiffuseMethod.Lambert());
 material.setSpecularMethod(new SpecularMethod.Phong());
 
 myObject.setMaterial(material);

        FragmentShader customFragmentShader)

    • Method Detail

      • usingVertexColors

        public boolean usingVertexColors()
        Indicates that this material should use a color value for every vertex. These colors are contained in a separate color buffer.
        Returns:
        A boolean indicating that vertex colors will be used.

      • useVertexColors

        public void useVertexColors(boolean value)
        Indicates that this material should use a color value for every vertex. These colors are contained in a separate color buffer.
        Parameters:
        value - A boolean indicating whether vertex colors should be used or not

      • setColor

        public void setColor(int color)
        The material's diffuse color. This can be overwritten by Object3D.setColor(int). This color will be applied to the whole object. For vertex colors use useVertexColors(boolean) and setVertexColors(int).
        Parameters:
        int - color The color to be used. Color.RED for instance. Or 0xffff0000.

      • setColor

        public void setColor(float[] color)
        The material's diffuse color. This can be overwritten by Object3D.setColor(int). This color will be applied to the whole object. For vertex colors use useVertexColors(boolean) and setVertexColors(int).
        Parameters:
        color - A float array containing the colors to be used. These are normalized values containing values for the red, green, blue and alpha channels.

      • getColor

        public int getColor()
        Returns this material's diffuse color.
        Returns:

      • setColorInfluence

        public void setColorInfluence(float influence)
        The color influence indicates how big the influence of the color is. This should be used in conjunction with ATexture.setInfluence(float). A value of .5 indicates an influence of 50%. This examples shows how to use 50% color and 50% texture: 
        
 material.setColorInfluence(.5f);
 myTexture.setInfluence(.5f);
        Parameters:
        influence - A value in the range of [0..1] indicating the color influence. Use .5 for 50% color influence, .75 for 75% color influence, etc.

      • getColorInfluence

        public float getColorInfluence()
        Indicates the color influence. Use .5 for 50% color influence, .75 for 75% color influence, etc.
        Returns:
        A value in the range of [0..1]

      • setAmbientColor

        public void setAmbientColor(int color)
        This material's ambient color. Ambient color is the color of an object where it is in shadow.
        Parameters:
        color - The color to be used. Color.RED for instance. Or 0xffff0000.

      • setAmbientColor

        public void setAmbientColor(float[] color)
        This material's ambient color. Ambient color is the color of an object where it is in shadow.
        Parameters:
        color - A float array containing the colors to be used. These are normalized values containing values for the red, green, blue and alpha channels.

      • getAmbientColor

        public int getAmbientColor()
        Returns this material's ambient color. Ambient color is the color of an object where it is in shadow.

      • setAmbientIntensity

        public void setAmbientIntensity(double r,
                       double g,
                       double b)
        This material's ambient intensity for the r, g, b channels.
        Parameters:
        r - The value [0..1] for the red channel
        g - The value [0..1] for the green channel
        b - The value [0..1] for the blue channel

        g - The value [0..1] for the green channel
        b - The value [0..1] for the blue channel

      • createShaders

        private void createShaders()
        Takes all material parameters and creates the vertex shader and fragment shader and then compiles the program. This method should only be called on initialization or when parameters have changed.

        public void bindTextures()
        Binds the textures to an OpenGL texturing target. Called every frame by RajawaliScene.render(double, rajawali.renderer.RenderTarget). Shouldn't be called manually.

      • enableLighting

        public void enableLighting(boolean value)
        Indicates whether lighting should be used or not. This must be set to true when using a DiffuseMethod or a SpecularMethod. Lights are added to a scene RajawaliScene and are automatically added to the material.
        Parameters:
        value -

      • lightingEnabled

        public boolean lightingEnabled()
        Indicates whether lighting should be used or not. This must be set to true when using a DiffuseMethod or a SpecularMethod. Lights are added to a scene RajawaliScene and are automatically added to the material.
        Returns:

      • enableTime

        public void enableTime(boolean value)
        Indicates that the time shader parameter should be used. This is used when creating shaders that should change during the course of time. This is used to accomplish effects like animated vertices, vertex colors, plasma effects, etc. The time needs to be manually updated using the setTime(float) method.
        Parameters:
        value -

      • timeEnabled

        public boolean timeEnabled()
        Indicates that the time shader parameter should be used. This is used when creating shaders that should change during the course of time. This is used to accomplish effects like animated vertices, vertex colors, plasma effects, etc. The time needs to be manually updated using the setTime(float) method.
        Returns:

      • setTime

        public void setTime(float time)
        Sets the time value that is used in the shaders to create animated effects. 
        
 public class MyRenderer extends RajawaliRenderer
 {
                private double mStartTime;
                private Material mMyMaterial;
 
                protected void initScene() {
                        mStartTime = SystemClock.elapsedRealtime();
                        ...
                }
 
                public void onDrawFrame(GL10 glUnused) {
                        super.onDrawFrame(glUnused);
                        mMyMaterial.setTime((SystemClock.elapsedRealtime() - mLastRender) / 1000d);
                        ...
                }
        Parameters:

      • setLights

        public void setLights(java.util.List<ALight> lights)
        The lights that affect the material. Lights shouldn't be managed by any other class than RajawaliScene. To add lights to a scene call {@link RajawaliScene#addLight(ALight).
        Parameters:
        lights - The lights collection

      • setDiffuseMethod

        public void setDiffuseMethod(IDiffuseMethod diffuseMethod)
        The diffuse method specifies the reflection of light from a surface such that an incident ray is reflected at many angles rather than at just one angle as in the case of specular reflection. This can be set using the setDiffuseMethod() method: 
        
 material.setDiffuseMethod(new DiffuseMethod.Lambert());
        Parameters:
        diffuseMethod - The diffuse method

      • getDiffuseMethod

        public IDiffuseMethod getDiffuseMethod()
        The diffuse method specifies the reflection of light from a surface such that an incident ray is reflected at many angles rather than at just one angle as in the case of specular reflection. This can be set using the setDiffuseMethod() method: 
        
 material.setDiffuseMethod(new DiffuseMethod.Lambert());
        Returns:
        the currently used diffuse method

      • setSpecularMethod

        public void setSpecularMethod(ISpecularMethod specularMethod)
        The specular method specifies the mirror-like reflection of light (or of other kinds of wave) from a surface, in which light from a single incoming direction (a ray) is reflected into a single outgoing direction. This can be set using the setSpecularMethod() method: 
        
 material.setSpecularMethod(new SpecularMethod.Phong());
        Parameters:
        specularMethod - The specular method to use

      • getSpecularMethod

        public ISpecularMethod getSpecularMethod()
        The specular method specifies the mirror-like reflection of light (or of other kinds of wave) from a surface, in which light from a single incoming direction (a ray) is reflected into a single outgoing direction. This can be set using the setSpecularMethod() method: 
        
 material.setSpecularMethod(new SpecularMethod.Phong());
        Returns:
        The currently used specular method

      • addPlugin

        public void addPlugin(IMaterialPlugin plugin)
        Add a material plugin. A material plugin is basically a class that contains a vertex shader fragment and a fragment shader fragment. Material plugins can be used for custom shader effects.
        Parameters:
        plugin -

      • getPlugin

        public IMaterialPlugin getPlugin(java.lang.Class<?> pluginClass)
        Get a material plugin by using its class type. A material plugin is basically a class that contains a vertex shader fragment and a fragment shader fragment. Material plugins can be used for custom shader effects.
        Parameters:
        pluginClass -
